title: Multimedia Search in the perspective of Future Internet Services

author: Joao Schwarz da Silva, Converged Networks and Services, European Commission

segmentation: Feel pleasure for me to be with you.
Here I was with you in Geneva sometime ago year and a half ago and I do consider chorus to be one of the most interesting and most efficient coordination actions we ever had.
In in the in amongst our projects because it does contribute to at least highlight the differences that exist and bring you together and the fact that they were coming together to exchange views.
It's very very positive.
Now.

In preparing this presentation, Louise told me that I had too many slides already 15 minutes late, so I'll try to go a bit quick even though the title of this is the role of multimedia search in future Internet it's it's a vast program, so I won't say much about that, but nevertheless there a couple of points I would like.
Commission.
For searches, is indeed one of the most intriguing issues that we have today.
I mean, we consider it to be to be at a stage where search is rather primitive.

And we're interested in Commission not in being mounting something against Google or against anyone else, but rather to project ourselves in the future so that we capture the markets of tomorrow, not fight against the markets of today.
But search is indeed multifaceted thing which is extremely complicated, and I would like to simply very quickly go through a number of things which I've came across my screen in the last.
2 three weeks.
You've heard about these Wolfram Alpha, which is interesting.
It's not really a search engine, but I've tried.
I've tried it and there you have it.
As you can see it.
I've asked the question Internet users in Europe.
He tells me that the Vatican there 93 users, which is something I've been.
Presumably you don't find.
In the in Google, so it it gives you this sort of information which is not bad.
Then we have the so called Google Squared which is coming up.
Then you have the Microsoft Engine which is most likely going to be called cool and then we have a couple of others which I find very interesting.
Whenever these I seek.

That has on the left these things here the targets which are extremely interesting, and they they really give you results, which in my view are much better than what Google has or can give you in terms of.
Of questions like the one that was posed simply saying future Internet, you can select the range of dates and a number of targets and that it works extremely well.
Then you have things like can you see from the Financial Times which again for those interested in going after press releases and news news of all kinds, it's extremely powerful.
So all of these to say that this there's a variety of things, and we in the Commission or not interested again in going after or fighting against a particular search engine.
There will be room for in the future for many.
Because this is really we're still in infancy and full of.
Search now a couple of remarks on search and or the fact that this is very much related to computing power.
First observation is that it is.
It looks extremely expensive and only those that have solid deep pockets can build.
A search, a search engine that captures the mass market.
Today I'm convinced that to go.
That's why I say I'm going to go after Google or MSN or any of these people that have.
The market shares of 1990% more it's it's extremely expensive and I'm not so sure that this is.
This is relevant as an activity.
What is important to note and this is what these remarks are about.
Is that because of the growth?
In terms of datasets of all kinds.
Including the information that is arises out of the Internet of Things.

There is an increasing need to have computing power, and if you look at the server parks around the world as taken up by Microsoft, Google, Yahoo and Amazon as an example, these people by 20% of the entire world production of servers.
Every year OK and this.
In terms of of numbers, means that 1,000,000 servers are bought by these companies every year.
So if you divide that by the number of.
Months I mean they they buy these things that then extra nomical and they buy them and set them up and then Saramacca rate.
This is this is absolutely staggering.
Just to see that these companies have have that much.
In terms of.
Computing power
Now, some of the multimedia challenges that very quickly that I think come across our minds is the fact that you see I would read all of these.
But one thing that strikes me is that eventually in the future would like to to be able to extract.
Everything from the web or from.
From variety, very two databases associated with information on a particular person.
Place or things that maybe.
That may be related to it to the person and this we don't know how to do today.
For instance, would like if you're interested in say, pollution, can you today, summarizer provide real time alerting on given types of pollution phrases?
On the basis of all European TV radio channels and cable monitor or whatever, it's it's being broadcast and the answer is no.
The 4th element, which is extremely important and more and more important, is the dimension of real time.

Even with engines like Google, if you compare them to things like Twitter in Twitter, things spread out instantaneously compared to Google where it takes some time before you can actually access the information.
So real time is is becoming.
Absolutely key.

A couple of things which in my view are also important, is that beyond what we classically know as datasets over which we, we, we search there all kinds of elements, such as those relating to sensing the city, and there are a couple of experiments out there, notably in San Francisco where as illustrated here in this map.
This is the emotions of people that happen to walk in the streets of San Francisco.
They're all provided with some sort of a. Sensor bays or device that allows them to express their feelings so you have Maps that can be generated.
And eventually this may lead to the need to search for data coming out of the city on which you express your feelings.

The other thing which of course is obvious is that beyond beyond what we know location, and this is the example of Google is is of course becoming more and more vital as as a piece of information over which one needs to.
To search for.
And if you look at mobile devices that may be fitted with sensors, this is the range of sensing capabilities that may be associated with a mobile device.
As an example, in there many more, but if this is the case, the question then arises is hard.
Why set up?
A search engine that allows him to capture this sort of information as captured by by a mobile device, especially if I'm dealing with populations.
It's likely in Europe where the penetration of mobile is well over 100%.
So how do we about go about collecting this?
This is not yet done.
But eventually this will come around.
Come about now a couple of numbers on what the Internet size.
Some of you have seen these figures, there's one which I think is interesting.
Which is the story of Facebook, Facebook?
Today's estimate they have 200 million.
Customers or appliance or users.
What is happening is that there all kinds of transactions going on within Facebook.
That are gradually replacing what people used to do outside of Facebook.
Take email.
Email now is is going down.
Worldwide, why?
Because people use Facebook as an exchange vehicle to do exactly what they used to do with email.
And this is going to happen.
With search as well, people who are not going to walk out of Facebook to search, they're going to be doing it within the social networks.
Because that is the amount of information being collected in these things, pictures, videos and so on.
So most of these activities will most likely happen within these social networks rather than outside of such networks.
And this of course has implications which are extremely important.
A couple of words about languages on the Internet you may not.
Realize it, but 70% of the languages in use in the Internet are not English.
70% of the people speak another language.
This is what is shown here.
English is about 28% say 30% so there.
The remainder is about 70%.
So this is, I mean, the English is the most spoken line in terms of numbers, but if you collect all of these, it's it's minority minority of people in on the web speak English.
And we are again used to search engines that only speak English.
And in China they don't know about Google.
They have they use other edge.

Another aspect which is important to mention is that users where will they come from in the future if today already have 70% of the users that speak and do not speak English in the future is going to be worse.
Huawei.
Look at the look at the numbers here.
Take North America.
This is the penetration rate.
Pretty high.
Europe is somewhere there say 50%.
In terms of users you have Asia.
That many users but the penetration rate is extremely low.
So when these people?
Eventually grow to penetration rates of that size.
This is going to be far higher than anything else, so the users most likely will come from elsewhere, North from North America, not from Europe.
A couple of additional observations on this.
If you look at the number of people that today are users of Web, excluding the mobile people, there's about 1.5 billion people worldwide.
But interesting Lee of these people, less than 100 sites are sites that people look at.
OK, out of the.
Thousands and thousands, if not millions of websites.
There's that less than 100 to take the bulk of the traffic.
Less than 10 reach more than 93%.
OK, so this implications are today.
The dominant players are also called Internet titles.
They mostly are US, but this is going to change.
No, a couple of words to simply mention.
For those that lack video, that video is increasing according to numbers that people provide.
Cisco and many others.
Videos is increasing at a very rapid pace by 2012, is expected at 50%.
With the traffic on, the net would be video traffic.
This is.
Reflected here, see this is.
This is the these two bars.
Here are the video bars OK, the bulk of it at 50%.
The rest is could also contain some video, but.
But this is to give you a feeling of how and then of course when we talk about video, we talk about searching over overheated material, which is.
Don't reveal.
Now a couple of words also about these devices that you certainly are aware of.
The only reason why I mentioned it is is that this device represents to us.
A pretty good illustration of the capability of the Nets too.
Change and change rapidly.
Think of a device that was introduced in July 2008.
How many applications when this was done, which is like a few months ago, the number of applications were out about 20,000.
Since then they have reached 40,000 applications.
This is April 2009.
The bulk of those applications are free.
Some are not and the Apple is estimated only makes 38 million euros or dollars out of these applications.
Nothing is absolutely nothing.
But the users who develop applications, they some of them, specially the ones that sell these applications for a price for a fee, they're doing quite well in terms of downloads almost.
I mean by now it's over 1 billion applications have been downloaded again, as I say, some are.
For free, the bulk is for free.
Many are for a fee, but this is an indication of the pace at which these things are happening.
So amongst the applications which are today the 40,000 on these devices, the interesting thing that you may not know is that this device can only hold simultaneously 148 applications.
So how do I even select applications?
Being confronted with and with a space of 40,000 applications growing at the rate of something like 1000 a week.
How do I go about finding the right application or the one that I'm interested in?
So up well.
And let me go faster.
So if you bring all of these elements together, I mean there are clear indications that.
In the next few years there will be a new Internet that will emerge out of this.
And this Internet is going to be.
Characterized primarily by being very pervasive and massively distributed, sensing and communication architecture infrastructure.
This is in our view and that's why we put so much emphasis on the Internet, the place where the economy of tomorrow is going to be created or invented for the time.
For the time being, it isn't, but it will be the case.
And that's why we're looking at sectors such as energy transport and many others as those sectors that correspond to social societal challenges where there will be scope for huge challenges.
Not notably, challenges in terms of search.
And in this information finding, I prefer the word finding rather than a word.
Search is absolutely vital.
There are ambition in putting forward this rich Internet as a paradigm that we should be working on is that.

Until now that you're pretty recently, what we have done is you can say it's efficient is effective, but we should go a lot lot further than that and we should really strive for projects and programs that have visible industrial impact.
This is one of the reasons why we have now recently.
Put forward the notion of a public Private Partnership project, which aims that channeling large sums of money into groups.
Industrial groups that have a visible and exploitation dimension in what they do.
We're concerned that the our competitiveness in the globalized environment needs to be addressed much better than it has been.
That's why we're doing it.
Now our strategy, so far as this is concerned is is threefold.
First we have the work program which is coming up 4000 Eleven 1013.
As you know, you have certainly made submitted proposals were called for.
There will be calls 6, seven and eight coming up in the next word program.
There is absolutely essential that we provide sufficient funds.
This in areas such as ones I've mentioned, but with with a different perspective.
Rather than seeking to have the best possible results in terms of science, we should as well look for approaching have.
And equally important, exploitation dimension.
We're going to be complementing the work program that which is classical work program by this thing which I refer to call the PPP there.

If you look at the sectors which I've mentioned, energy, health, transportation, we believe that this is an area or those are areas or sectors where there's huge scope for innovation and huge scope for doing things that the market players will not necessarily do by themselves.
So if we give them a push, perhaps.
We we can engineer something.
Which is good for competitiveness reasons and for job creation.
Particularly finally, our strategy is also based on the creation of a forum of Member States.

We've asked all the Member States to come together and discuss and amazingly, they have met for the first time last couple weeks ago in Prague and it was amazing to see that they had never met to discuss these things.
And there is all kinds of interesting initiatives growing in various Member States.
The last one, which I have seen in case you have, you don't know it.
There is France is issued a consultation.
Document.
Asking for people to express themselves as to what future Internet is all about.
So it's just one amongst many, many such.
Initiatives.
So for you, this is my last slide.
You really have to demonstrate that your community is is ready.
To help in this process, and as I said, there will be ample opportunities for you to demonstrate how effective you can be.
You have to identify not what you're going to be doing against Google, but what you can do in terms of creating opportunities.
Perhaps in what are considered to be today niche markets, but tomorrow won't be in each markets.
Multimedia search in particular is because of the fact that video and all of these things are going to be increasing in terms of usage.
Certainly very important and key component of this future Internet.
And in a nutshell, if you can help us.
Define latest strategy for what Europe should be done.
Would be delighted to help in counting your support.
Thank you very much for your attention.
